author: hfutrell
body:
That’s true. But Apple also has 3x the market share in PCs that it did when it made the PowerPC to Intel transition roughly 15 years ago. From that perspective they are in a position of relative strength.

Consider also how important the web is today versus 15 years ago. And consider how subscription app business models means that important apps like Adobe Creative Suite and Microsoft Office will be available to customers at no additional cost as soon as they are ready (likely day one).

 The transition will leave some apps behind, but on a relative scale it won’t be that disruptive to most customers.

author: 4121Laurel
body:
No although you’re very invested in technology
Which isn’t a bad thing.  
- AAPL is great, their market value will always go back to what it was even if they don’t release the new iPhone. Don’t be afraid of a drop just average costs if it drops dramatically. 

- Adobe should do well with this stay at home. School is requiring the use as well as businesses from home. 

- Amazon is essentially showing its untouchable currently. I’m large into amazon as well. 

- Disney is another powerhouse that you’ll never need to worry about. The lost revenues over the following 8 months could cause a dramatic drop, in this scenario don’t panic and average your cost. 

- Enph - energy, I’m not familiar with this company. 

- Facebook is another powerhouse good pick. 

- Google - Great pick. 

- MasterCard is also a good pick, hold this. Average if it comes down to although you shouldn’t have to they trade rather high. If you’re at a major loss with their recent decline. Average in the next 3 months when there’s a better understanding how financials will deal with crisis. (You shouldn’t need to) 

- Microsoft - I love microsoft. They are on a tear currently. Teams daily usage is up 12 million users in the last month, this is major. Their competition is “work” slack technologies who I am also Long. 

- Netflix has been great good pick. 

- Nike is a great pick. I could expand but they’ve always done well. Constant increase throughout the life of their stock. 

- Nvidia is a powerhouse as well. Great pick. 

- Starbucks is great. I haven’t followed them through the virus but they’re a strong company large capital, their profits are also great. Good pick. 

- Square I like square a lot. Square has major potential in different avenues. Cash app, lending (they just got approved to lend during this time). Prior to the virus square was on a tear. I’m long on this I got in early and am very big on square. 

If you’re interested in diversification:

All that being said you really are big into tech, I would suggest diversification. 

“Oxy” - occidental petroleum is a good long term stock. They’re trading extremely low currently due to oil wars, corona virus, issues on the board and the purchase of anadarko. (This scares a lot of investors but you seem to want long term investments) it’s a steal at 15$ a share. 

- Johnson and Johnson is a powerhouse. 

- Jet blue & Delta - long term great investments. Short term extremely risky. 

- Walmart: trading high but they’re only going to go even higher when this is over. 

- AT&T and Verizon: AT&T trades fairly low with a large dividend. GREAT LONG TERM. Verizon has been extremely strong throughout the years.  

- Ford on the long term has a lot of upside trading around half of its average price. Ford pays dividend and  history has proven America will never let ford fail. 

- USO is an ETF that tracks United States Oil, It’s trading extremely low, no reason not to diversify with this. ( The oil war between Saudi and Russia is coming to an end, this should do well in the long term) 

- Have you put any though into mutual funds to also diversify ? A good managed funds typically has large returns and low risk. 

Reach out to me if you’d like.

author: CrimsonBrit
body:
I appreciate the thought and effort that went into this write-up, however, you've done quite a bit of due diligence to ultimately pick 80% of the **FAANG** stocks (Facebook ($FB), Amazon ($AMZN), Apple ($AAPL), Netflix ($NFLX); and Alphabet ($GOOG) with Netflix being the one you did not pick in your list of six companies.

Each of the FAANG stocks trades on the Nasdaq exchange and is included in the S&P 500 Index. Since the S&P 500 is a broad representation of the market, where the FAANGs make up about 15% of the S&P 500—a staggering figure considering the S&P 500 is generally viewed as a proxy for the United States economy as a whole,  you have basically just invested in the market as a whole, as stated by /u/Chuckox50.

Not to mention that investing in Berkshire ($BRK.A) is like investing in an index fund of sorts, where Berkshire's "fund" also owns positions in Apple (33.9%), Amazon (0.57%), and Johnson & Johnson (0.24%), adding to your positions in those three companies. Additionally, Berkshire owns relatively small positions in the SPDR S&P 500 ETF Trust ([$SPY](https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/SPY:US)) and VANGUARD IX FUN/S&P 500 ETF SHS NEW ([$VOO](https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/VOO:US)) ETFs, which both track the S&P 500 and in turn have positions in some of the companies you have mentioned: Microsoft ($MSFT), Apple, Amazon, Facebook, Berkshire, Johnson & Johnson, and Alphabet.

**That being said, I still think that they are rock-solid choices and I have several of those on my radar and just as many already in my portfolio, and I intend to add to my positions for those companies.**

I am investing for the long-term and currently have a high tolerance for risk, so the majority of the stocks on my lengthy list of about 55 companies on my radar right now are tech.

Just to mention a bunch of them (on top of MSFT, AAPL, GOOG, NFLX, FB, and AMZN):

* Financial: Visa, Mastercard, PayPal, Square
* Healthcare: JNJ, UnitedHealth, AbbVie, Illumina, InVitae
* Services: AMZN, Walmart, Disney, Spotfiy
* Technology (Software): Oracle, Adobe, Salesforce, Shopify, Splunk, Docusign, Twiliio, The Trade Desk
* Technology (Gaming): Activision Blizzard, Take-Two
* Technology (Semiconductors): Intel, NVIDIA, AMD, Micron, Teradyne
* Telecom/Communications: Verizon, AT&T, Cisco

I would like to caution you for your analysis in the write-up in regards to Berkshire. You state that your rationale for Berkshire having a competitive edge post-COVID-19 is simply "Warren Buffett". By the time that COVID is on the decline, Buffett will be 90 years old. I think the company can thrive without him, but if your basis for investing in that company for the long-term is a man born in 1930, I think you need to reassess your rationale.

So yes, I certainly like this sector for the long-term (quite a bit) but I would patiently wait for opportunities and add over time rather than just  piling in at this point.

author: spicyricerocket
body:
Hey there--happy to give some feedback. I think your portfolio overall looks pretty decent, provided that you genuinely understand these companies and bought at reasonable prices. A good number of these companies have sustainable competitive advantages and good management, so you're off to a great start. Time is on your side, and since you're in your early 20s, there's no problem with being 100% in equities. In fact, if there was a time in your life to do so, it'd probably be now while you can afford the risk. 

One point of contention that I'd like to mention is the equal weighting. Is that purposefully done? Personally, I think it's unnecessary. There's definitely a few companies in that portfolio in which you have much better understanding and conviction. Turn up the exposure on those (if they are at least fairly valued). For me, that would be DIS, MSFT, NKE, and ADBE, but for you that could be different.

To answer your question is "14...too many to hold in a portfolio?" I think no. Personally, I believe it's pointless to fixate on how many stocks you own. If you've got even 3 or 4 great holdings, what's holding #5 really going to do for you? Diversification for the sake of it, especially in these current market conditions, is irrational in my view. Great companies are really rare, and that's something I've come to appreciate over my investing journey. Spend time finding the truly exceptional organizations and run with them. Good luck!

author: firestormdude
body:
I’m a web developer and programmer who’s tracked the trends in e-commerce. Shopify is by far the most robust platform for small businesses and it’s subscription based at a reasonable price people can afford to pay each month. It includes payment processing as well as part of the monthly fee.

From my experience, people are very slow to cancel subscriptions tied to their websites, especially when it’s not breaking the bank. This is how Shopify retains its business and continues to grow.

It’s competition has never and will likely never catch up. I’ve used platforms like BigCommerce, Magento, and even dated a gal that worked at Volusion in Austin and none of them stack up with what Shopify offers.

Shopify is right up there with Adobe and Salesforce as a great growth stock to own with all subscription based revenue. However, I would not buy a ton right now until the market takes out its March lows given the current circumstances in the economy. We definitely have not hit bottom yet in the market and have a ways to fall.

author: Electric_pokemon
body:
1)I think the industry dominance you are talking about is mostly smaller and mid sized customers - Adobe Magento and Salesforce Demandware are very capable and competitive solutions up market. If anything, they are the go to solutions for Enterprise.

2) Shopify has a lot of exposure to VC backed D2C companies, many of which are now struggling for life. The room to growth becomes very questionable when a lot of these e-commerce companies have been burning cash, the whole model is now under question. VC funding has stopped, completely.

Dropshipping is likely to be another casualty in post COVID world - cheap stuff from China, which is mostly consumer discretionary, isn't going to grow 50% a year with unemployment rising, if anything businesses will see declining sales of these. You might see unemployed people starting more of these business, but they'll not offset decline in merchant solutions revenue (dependent on sales).

3) Unlike Amazon, Shopify doesn't control it's destiny. It relies on its sellers to be successful. I do like the fulfilment aspect but again, Shopify relies on its sellers to be successful selling through their own marketing- it doesn't bring organic traffic to its customers the way Amazon does. Amazon has achieved the unthinkable - no one foresaw AWS for example.

author: MicroBadger_
body:
The economic data is massively lagging/under reported.  Take today's [ADP report](https://adpemploymentreport.com/common/docs/ADP-NER-Methodology-Full-Detail.pdf).  They just look at who was on the payrolls for the period that includes March 12th.  So unless your paid monthly. We're talking the majority of that data goes out to March 13th tops.  In addition if folks are on the payrolls but not collecting a paycheck (would be a good # of folks initially) they aren't counted as having lost their job. 

 The scale of the "stay at home" orders just isn't being realized yet.  The market is seeing under reported data, thinking "that's not as bad as we thought" and going up because of it.  I think once we start getting more of those numbers in April/May time frame, we're going to start seeing the true scope of damage we're enduring and the market will start going a lot lower.

author: mikwow
body:
OK YOU AUTISTS I'M GONNA SAY THIS ONCE

* On Wednesday, the ADP releases private payrolls. It uses the week that includes the 12th of the month as a reference week.

* On Thursday, the Department of Labor releases initial jobless claims from the week before. That's the important piece of data this week because it includes data from when states were on lockdown.

* On Friday the BLS releases the official employment report for the month of March. Just like the ADP, the survey uses the week including the 12th of the month as the reference week. Again, most businesses were still open during that week so we will have to wait for the April report to see the extent of the damage from the pandemic.

author: SportsDogsDollars
body:
I think Calgary and Edmonton will take a trim (might be small, but could be a big trim). They never did have a strong bounce back from the 2015 debacle. Now with the 1-2 punch of oil layoffs and corona virus some people are fucked and panicking. I have the following comments to support a decline in Calgary specifically: 

\-Job losses in oil and layoffs from COVID

\-The market hadn't fully bounced back since 2015

\-There's already a huge influx of fully furnished apartments hitting websites like RentFaster. People's investment properties that run on Air BNB are now empty and burning holes in their pockets. The market can only absorb so many of these rentals hitting the market at once. Few people want to move apartments in this environment, so its quite plausible these units will have to be put up for sale. Then you have even more folks forced to sell, without an increase in buyers. 

\- Using a specific example. There was a 1 BR+den unit in Mission (Young but nice area, within walking distance of downtown Calgary) for $293K. It was being used for short term rentals. This week the priced dropped $75K to $218K. 

I'm expecting some more fire sales out of desperation (job losses and empty investment properties) which will drag down the price of most sales. Long term though there could be 1 last boom in AB oil and gas. Should TMX, KXL and Enbridge Line 3 replacement all be executed and put into service, the mid 2020s could provide 1 last big hurrah for Canadian Oil.

body:
**Thoughts on APT Calls?**

**Original** \- Entered a call debit spread $11/$13 @ $0.98. Exp: 4/9 Reason I did a spread and not naked was due to lack of capital at time being.

I'm new to TA but wanted to try using what seem to be the most intuitive indicators for me - RSI, VWAP, and 50/200 MA.

**My DD**

When I entered the position, RSI seemed good but has gone up to 56 now, so that's got me a little bit worried.

However, APT has crossed and come over the 50MA line 3 times in the last 5 days, which I read now as a support rather than a distance. It has also directly bounced off the 200MA which is good to see as well.

Market EOD was $18.xx or so, but VWAP is around $15\~. Perhaps a good entry tomorrow for a long position will be if it returns to VWAP, but regarding the explosiveness and nature of the stock I'm also debating just buying ASAP with expiry for next week.

As for the strike price I'm looking at, I'm looking at around $25/26, which is where it peaked last time in early march.

**Sentiment** \- Talks about Americans getting used to the idea of having to wear masks. The thing is 3M, DuPont, etc. make PPE (personal protection equipment) but really APT has been sort of the front man of that for a while now. 

With fear going to spike up again this week, I think it'll be good to get in and take a long. Plus volume was only 20 million today, so hasn't been "discovered" by the media yet. 

Any tips/advice for a newbie would be very beneficial.

author: Nutmasher
body:
So looking at it on a 2 min, this recent bottom and churn at 2445-2525 has exposed the weakness of this technique.
MA crossovers do not fair well in sideways markets unless you scalp... Get out before the turn.
Even my 10-40 sma crossover gives false signals.
Obviously, the goal is to ride some wave higher.  It's coming today or next week, but this week, using this method is a bust.
I bought a 5% position in SSO Wednesday at a crossover signal (~2500), but ended up holding it vs selling on a down signal.  I did that because I knew price would cover back to this level.  Then, as prices hit the 78.6% retracement, I added another 5%.  O added a third 5% on another retracement Thursday.
I held these 3 positions until Thursday pm.  Sold for $2000 gain.

So it was a combination of...
1. Moving average crossover entry.
2. Dollar cost averaging on retracements.
3. Fib levels for entry.
4. Double top level for exit (Thursday high).

A lot more work than the casual investor is looking for.  But if I strictly followed the buy/sell at the signal, I would have lost money.  Probably the same $2000.

author: HockeyCoachHere
body:
Reasonable options, but they all have notable downfalls.

One of the big ones is that a centralized blockchain will never suffice to replace something like Visa.

The current international transaction rate of credit cards peaks around 25,000 per second (christmas eve of 2019) combining major brands (visa, mastercard, etc)

Cash is probably significantly higher than that worldwide.

For a currency to "replace" money or credit cards or banks, as the long-term stated goal of crypto enthusiasts, it has to scale to numbers on the order of thousands of transactions per second.

Bitcoin, Zcash and Monero as they are designed, are all fundamentally centralized public blockchains that implement various forms of anonymization for wallet transactions.  

However, in reality, it's probably not practical for all nodes to know about all transactions everywhere in the world at all times.   That requirement fundamentally means that every node everywhere has to constantly consume 5-20mbps of incoming transaction data, 24/7/365 and that's assuming no significant growth in transaction volumes.

Even with aggressive pruning of transactions, the volume of data to accurately summarize the net worth of 7 billion people plus their various businesses, teams, organizations, accounts and otherwise would be extraordinary (trillions of transactions, at least - possibly a petabyte of data).

In the current blockchain concept, any transactions that have any significant notable value to the network have to be recorded on this chain, or they can't be verified.  Concepts like lightening network on bitcoin can "shard" some of this off, but these side transactions are fundamentally unverified, and the money used in them is fundamentally locked out of the main wallet of anyone using these channels, making them practical for certain activities (say, buying some gum), but impractical for something like transacting your rent, or any other dollar value that you value.

Some concepts of more broad global sharding of the main chain exist, but under "proof of work" that doesn't really work well without establishing "trusted nodes" to referee the sharding and that doesn't make the decentralization proponents happy.

It's probably possible to design something, maybe using a proof of stake system with stakeholders pooled into smaller shards, but that runs a greater risk of having network takeovers, unless you have a referee system that patrols for large movements of stakeholders into shards in order to pool stakes and subvert the voting system for monetary gain.

It's not a solved problem and no platform currently exists that could plausibly take over world currency transactions, or even a smaller credit card player like Discover, in terms of size and volume.

Proof of work, in my opinion, is a poor tech and while I play in crypto as a speculative instrument, I view it like a penny stock in a worthless industry from a true fundamentals perspective.

But that's just my educated opinion.

author: Marnsy16
body:
#Les yeux qui brillent, la conscience qui s'éteint
Cerveau troué comme ma paire de Vans
Seul au milieu du passage piéton
La faucheuse me fait des appels de phares
Le calme intérieur, la belle face
Changent tout c'que j'ai sous la chair en pierre
Change la tisane de mon verre en bière
Envie d'envoyer chier la Terre entière
La vie est une imparfaite perfection
Chaque jour je subis de nouvelles pressions
Le futur s'arrangera comme Urion
Je disparais des caméras d'surveillance
Dehors les miens sont traités comme des chiens
Monsieur policier nous respecte pas
La nuit, possédé comme un comédien
Je m'endors à l'heure où le spectre part
Torturé, quand les pensées claquent la porte du réel
Petit, c'était dur d'être torturé
C'est encore dur et ça va encore durer
En silence, je presse le pas
Tant de galères pour un si vieux parcours
Les coïncidences n'existent pas
Chaque seconde, je vois des signes partout
Et puis y a cette femme, envie de lui dire
"Grâce à nos baises, j'apprécie mieux chaque jour"
Peur qu'elle s'efface, envie de lui dire
Un soir avec des petits jeux d'amour
Même en été, j'ai peu chaud sans toi
Tout allait mieux quand on roulait sur ma Peugeot 103
